title: Italian authorities evacuate 4,000 from city centre as bomb squad defuse World War Two explosive
text:
Italian authorities were forced to evacuate 4,000 people from a busy city centre after a World War Two bomb was discovered.

The explosive device was found in Piazza Verdi in Bolzano, northern Italy, by builders working on a construction site in the area.

Thousands were shepherded out of their homes as bomb disposal squads were drafted in to neutralise the threat.

Italian authorities evacuated 4,000 people after an explosive device was found in Piazza Verdi, in Bolzano, northern Italy, by builders working on a construction site in the area

The bomb was successfully diffused this morning after a three-hour operation, according to the news agency ANSA.

It was then winched out of the gully and transported away from the area in a wooden crate on the back of a flat-bed truck.

The evacuees were then informed that the city centre had been given the all clear when an alarm blared out across the city.

The nearby north-south highway and a rail line connecting Italy with Austria and Germany were also re-opened.

Thousands were shepherded out of their homes as bomb disposal squads (pictured) were drafted in to neutralise the threat

The bomb was successfully diffused this morning after a three-hour operation before it was winched out of the gully (pictured)

The artillery shell was identified as an aerial bomb dating back to WWII by local media outlet Neue Suedtiroler Tageszeitung.

Given its position bordering Austria, Bolzano suffered 13 major bombing raids during the major war which lasted from 1939 to 1945.

Collectively the raids damaged 60 per cent of the city and killed 200 people, according to historian Ettore Frangipane.
